A simple question and a damning revelation from @hammersmithandy in the House this morning. If the government claims to be serious about fraud, why has the Crown Prosecution Service cut its number of specialist fraud prosecutors by more than a quarter in the last six years? https://t.co/yNULBm8qgV

We need root and branch reform of how we tackle fraud as a country, from making it easier to prosecute wrong-doing by the major corporations to including scam ads in the scope of the Online Harms Bill. Fraud is the UK’s No1 crime, and it’s high time we treated it as such.

But Suella Braverman is kidding herself if she thinks this review will fix the government’s utterly hopeless approach to tackling fraud. When Lord Roskill’s 1986 report led to the creation of the SFO, this was what he said in Para 1, Page 1. Would he say any different today? 8/9 https://t.co/eHrJ0f9l7I

Today, two months after she announced a review into the Unaoil case, the Attorney General got round to appointing someone to lead it, and announcing his terms of reference. I wish Sir David Calvert-Smith well in his work and look forward to seeing the outcome. 7/9

The Unaoil debacle is not a one-off. It is part of a consistent failure on the part of the SFO to effectively prosecute cases of corporate fraud and corruption, and a first instinct when wrong-doing is detected, not to investigate those responsible, but negotiate with them. 6/9

In December 2021, the Court of Appeal found that the SFO’s failure to disclose the ‘embarrassing’ evidence of it contacts with Tinsley meant Akle had not had a fair trial, and decided to quash his five-year sentence. No-one else has faced jail time over the Unaoil fraud. 5/9 https://t.co/0yPVE6cyCD

When Akle was originally tried, the SFO did not disclose these dealings or any other evidence of the frequent contact SFO staff had with Tinsley. Kevin Davies – the SFO’s Chief Investigator – ‘accidentally’ deleted his phone data, for the second time in less than a year. 4/9 https://t.co/3mpXjZoj89

Tinsley contacted the Director of the SFO Lisa Osofsky, pitching himself as a middleman between the SFO and FBI. The Court of Appeal record shows a “super honoured” Osofsky organising a "solid hour together" with Tinsley to discuss the case. No notes were made of the meeting. 3/9 https://t.co/FcUGZ4RZvP

When investigators closed in on consultancy firm Unaoil over acts of bribery, its owners hired a ‘fixer’, David Tinsley, to get them off the hook. He pressured more junior employees like Mr Akle to plead guilty, and lobbied the Serious Fraud Office to let them take the fall. 2/9

After it was reported that Liz Truss likes to write ‘TL/DR’ on official memos, I said in response ‘You can’t TL/DR trade deals’. Nor can you just cut and paste old EU deals and hope they suit the UK’s bespoke needs. This freeports fiasco shows exactly why. https://t.co/Srg2KfoUdi

I asked Liz Truss recently what she was doing to promote freeports, and I got the response that it was a ‘domestic policy’, not something she was focused on. She’s going to have to start, because this blunder needs to be rectified urgently, before the freeports start work (6/6).

Inexplicably, despite that warning, Liz Truss went on to sign TEN more agreements containing the same prohibition clauses, including with Canada, Singapore, Norway, and Mexico, meaning UK manufacturers based in freeports can’t benefit from those trade agreements (5/6).

In the small print of their November ‘freeports bidding prospectus’, the Treasury identified this problem and warned potential bidders they might not qualify for tariff reductions on exports to a number of countries with whom the UK had signed rollover deals since 2019 (4/6).

One of the key advantages for manufacturers based in the new freeports is that they can import components and materials duty free, transform them into finished goods, and then export them around the world. A prohibition clause inevitably scuppers that advantage (3/6).

When DIT Ministers were negotiating rollover deals to maintain our free trade after Brexit, they failed to remove ‘prohibition clauses’ from 23 of those deals, which stop manufacturers who don’t pay duty on their imports from getting lower tariffs on their exports (2/6).

Here’s my letter to Liz Truss exposing the catastrophic negotiating blunder that risks leaving manufacturers in the UK’s new generation of freeports shut out of £35bn in export markets, as reported by the FT, the Indie and others today. A short thread to explain (1/6). https://t.co/KK2Y4ysuqt

Thanks to everyone who took part today in such an invigorating and varied discussion across the full range of trade issues. It shows not just how much there is to discuss, but how interested so many people are, so let’s keep that debate going in the crucial months ahead. #Trade21

Great discussion on the UK's exports of riot gear equipment to the US and its impact on human rights. Now we have a question from David who asks how we can ensure that products we import are not the product of exploited labour. #Trade21
Important question from Nicholas about the role of multilateralism in protecting human rights around the world. #Trade21

Shadow Minister for Women and Equalities @charlotte2153 asks whether the UK should be doing trade deals with countries who continue to criminalise and persecute members of the LGBTQ+ community. #Trade21 🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️

Our chair @GarethThomasMP kicks us off by asking when the panel first became conscious of and angry about the clash between the interests of trade and business, and the protection of human rights. #Trade21

Our final panel of the day 'Protecting Human Rights Through Trade' starts in 20 minutes! We will be joined by our chair @GarethThomasMP, @Bonn1eGreer, @WarChildUK's Rocco Blume, and @CAATuk's Andrew Smith. #Trade21

ActionAid's @IsabelleYounane asks a great question outlining just how little time Parliament has to assess the impacts of new trade deals on the UK's development goals, and in particular their impact on women and low-paid workers. @actionaiduk #Trade21
Now we're discussing how we can harness a green industrial strategy as a way to guide our trade and investment approach, following a great question from @MiriamBrett #Trade21 🍃

Secretary General of the International Chamber of Commerce @chrisouthworth asks how we can ensure that the UN Sustainable Development Goal becomes more prominent as a framework for recovery through trade. #Trade21
Deputy Director of the University of Sussex Trade Policy Observatory @LydgateEmily asks how the UK can use trade agreements to help implement its net-zero target. #Trade21

Following @ayeshahazarika's theme of 'girl power', part of our brilliant all-female panel @RuthBergan says what she 'really really wants' is for people to understand how important trade is to women. #Trade21 #SpiceGirls
.@ayeshahazarika kicks us off in the hope that Tony Abbott is listening by asking why the issue of international trade is too important to be left to men. #Trade21 👭

Our third panel 'Building a Sustainable Future' is about to begin. I'm delighted to be joined by our chair @ayeshahazarika, @jeanblaylock, @RuthBergan and South African High Commissioner Thembi Tambo to discuss the environment, development, and trade justice. #Trade21 🌏🍃
Our final question comes from @DavidBowles21 at  @RSPCA_official. He asks how the UK can influence and be a leader at the WTO on issues such as animal welfare 🐖🐔🐄 #Trade21
The NHS should not be on the table in any trade deal. @DrTonyOSullivan asks whether the only realistic way to protect the NHS is through legislation. #Trade21

Now two questions about food and animal welfare standards. @DanielZeichner asks what red lines there should be to protect food standards in trade deals, while @James_CIWF asks how we can protect animal welfare and British farmers in post-Brexit trade. #Trade21
Nick Crook from Unison reflects on the state of workers' rights in Colombia and asks a question about the enforceability of labour rights in trade agreements @nickcrook65 #Trade21
To kick off our second panel of the day, Deborah asks how we can ensure that the additional costs of post-Brexit trade do not result in lower wages and higher prices. #Trade21

Join us at 11.30 for our second panel on 'Raising Standards Around the World', where we'll be joined by @Bill_Esterson, @Rosa_Crawford, Ben Richards, and @AdamPosen to discuss how we can protect labour rights, public services and animal welfare in trade #Trade21
Final question from @edballs is about looking to the future. He asks what we will look back at in 10 years time and wish we had been discussing more when formulating trade policy. #Trade21
Mark asks where the UK can be world-class, create mass employment, and offer high value-added, high wage jobs. #Trade21
.@g_lanktree asks what strategies the government could undertake to promote trade and investment in the UK that aren't currently being leveraged to their full potential #Trade21
Great first question from @DeborahMeaden on how the UK should navigate our future relationship with the EU, our largest trading partner, after the 1st January 2021. #Trade21

I’ve written a little more about the historical precedent set by William Gladstone when he called an election after seeing his flagship legislation on the government of Ireland defeated by just 30 votes in 1886: https://t.co/flVz1WlB4z https://t.co/1lgpCbsQBK

Theresa May didn't just lose this vote by 200 more than Gladstone (230 vs 30), but with 25 more of her own MPs rebelling against her than rebelled against him (118 vs 93). If she has any sense of honour, she must follow his lead and call an election.

In 1886, Gladstone lost the vote on his Home Rule Bill by 30 votes, and felt obliged to call an election as a result. For Theresa May to do anything otherwise after the scale of this defeat would be utter cowardice. A reminder of my @Guardian article: https://t.co/kBzOSIuJNR
